user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_param__timeout:
```c
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
process_param__timeout (const char *param_name, const char *param_tail,
                        const char *next_param)
{
  unsigned int param_value;
  enum PerfRepl_param_result value_res;

  value_res = get_param_value (param_name, param_tail, next_param,
                               &param_value);
  if (PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR == value_res)
    return value_res;

  tool_params.timeout = param_value;
  return value_res;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function process_param__timeout:
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
get_param_value (const char *param_name, const char *param_tail,
                 const char *next_param, unsigned int *param_value)
{
  const char *value_str;
  size_t digits;
  if (0 != param_tail[0])
  {
    if ('=' != param_tail[0])
      value_str = param_tail;
    else
      value_str = param_tail + 1;
  }
  else
    value_str = next_param;

  if (NULL != value_str)
    digits = mhd_tool_str_to_uint (value_str, param_value);
  else
    digits = 0;

  if ((0 == digits) || (0 != value_str[digits]))
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' is not followed by valid number.\n",
             param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }

  if (0 != param_tail[0])
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_FULL_STR;

  return PERF_RPL_PARAM_STR_PLUS_NEXT;
}
...
enum PerfRepl_param_result
{
  PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR,        /**< Error processing parameter */
  PERF_RPL_PARAM_ONE_CHAR,     /**< Processed exactly one character */
  PERF_RPL_PARAM_FULL_STR,     /**< Processed current parameter completely */
  PERF_RPL_PARAM_STR_PLUS_NEXT /**< Current parameter completely and next parameter processed */
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No controlling expressions in the provided code are constant/invariant. Each conditional depends on function parameters or on values computed at run-time:

- In process_param__timeout: the test (PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR == value_res) depends on value_res returned by get_param_value.
- In get_param_value: the tests (0 != param_tail[0]) and ('=' != param_tail[0]) depend on the contents of param_tail; (NULL != value_str) depends on runtime assignment of value_str; digits is computed by mhd_tool_str_to_uint, so ((0 == digits) || (0 != value_str[digits])) depends on that result and the run-time contents of value_str; the final (0 != param_tail[0]) similarly depends on param_tail.

None of these are compile-time constant expressions or otherwise invariant for all executions, and no infinite-loop/do-while exceptions from Rule 14.3 apply here. Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation for Rule 14.3 compliance.
